content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act" or the "SECURE Act." Legal recourse for consumers is provided. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements. Injunctive relief can include costs and attorney fees for the prevailing party. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements, including costs and attorney fees for the prevailing party. The court may award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, with costs and attorney fees for the prevailing party. The Act is also amended to include negligent and willful violations in addition to knowing violations. Increased requirements for consumer reporting agencies and furnishers of information are mandated under Section 3. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include all documentation provided by consumers in the reporting process. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include all documentation provided by consumers in the reporting process, such as relevant information and documentation from the consumer or reseller. This includes reviewing and considering all relevant information, including documentation, provided by the consumer with the notice. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include gathering and reporting information relating to consumer disputes, requiring the Bureau to provide reports on disputes received by consumer reporting agencies. The Bureau is required to provide reports on consumer disputes received by reporting agencies, with rules set for gathering information and determining the format and frequency of data submission. The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires consumer reporting agencies to follow procedures to ensure accurate consumer reports. The Bureau sets rules for the type, format, and frequency of information received from reporting agencies. The Bureau must issue a proposed rule within a year to ensure maximum accuracy of consumer reports. Considerations include matching first and last names for improved accuracy. The Bureau will consider matching consumer information like names, date of birth, social security number, and other relevant data to improve the accuracy of consumer reports. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies and disclosures to consumers, including providing address and telephone number of the person and the permissible purpose for obtaining the consumer report. Amendments also require supplying consumers with credit scores derived from widely distributed credit scoring models for credit transactions. Amendments also require supplying consumers with credit scores derived from widely distributed credit scoring models for credit transactions, with the provision for free credit score requests in connection with annual consumer reports. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to provide consumers with free credit scores upon request in connection with annual consumer reports. Amendments also include notification requirements for adverse information and offer of credit on less favorable terms. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require consumer reporting agencies to provide free disclosures within 14 days of receiving notification of adverse action or offer of credit on less favorable terms. The Fair Credit Reporting Act now mandates that consumer reporting agencies must give consumers a free copy of their credit report and other required disclosures within 14 days of adverse action or credit offer on less favorable terms. The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires consumer reporting agencies to provide consumers with a free copy of their credit report and necessary disclosures within 14 days of adverse action or less favorable credit terms. This includes directing the agency to give the consumer the disclosures described in section 612(b) and informing the consumer that they will receive a free copy of their consumer report. The Fair Credit Reporting Act mandates that consumers receive a free copy of their credit report from the reporting agency within 14 days of adverse action or less favorable credit terms. Amendments include ensuring consumers are informed of their right to dispute information and updating notification requirements. Amendments to the Fair Credit Reporting Act include changes to paragraphs, redesignating paragraphs, and inserting a new paragraph regarding consumer reports. These changes aim to ensure consumers are notified of their rights and receive necessary disclosures. The amendments to the Fair Credit Reporting Act include directing consumer reporting agencies to provide consumers with required disclosures and defining certain disclosure requirements through a proposed rule by the Bureau. The Bureau must publish a proposed rule within a year of the Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act's enactment to implement disclosure requirements for consumers to understand reasons for adverse actions or less favorable credit terms, while ensuring consumer privacy. SEC. 4. REGULATORY REFORM. Section 621 of the Federal Credit Reporting Act is amended to establish 3 publicly available registries of consumer reporting agencies, including nationwide consumer reporting agencies, nationwide specialty consumer reporting agencies, and other consumer reporting agencies. All consumer reporting agencies are required to register. The Federal Credit Reporting Act is amended to require all consumer reporting agencies to register with one of the registries established by the Bureau. SEC. 5. STUDY OF A PUBLIC CREDIT REPORTING SYSTEM. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on international credit systems, accuracy of existing consumer credit reporting systems, feasibility of a national system, consumer benefits, and costs. Findings will be published within 18 months. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on international credit systems, accuracy of existing consumer credit reporting systems, feasibility of a national system, consumer benefits, and costs. Findings will be published within 18 months, including any costs that might result from a government-administered consumer credit reporting system in the United States. The provisions of this Act and its amendments will take effect 6 months after enactment, unless otherwise specified.
